720595f-a.text:

Neg 2427

711306f-a.text:
14th Street, south side, west from St. Bernard's Church (330 West 14th Street) to Hudson Street and Ninth Avenue, inclusive. St. Bernard's Roman Catholic Church, the first New York church to be dedicated by an American cardinal, was built in the face of the economic depression of the 1870's by the new parish laid out in 1868 by Cardianl McCloskey. The cornerstone was laid in May, 1873, and the church dedicated May 31, 1875.  A contemporty drawing of it shows a conical spire surmounting each tower, either these were never completed, or they were later taken off.
The six-story building at 342 West 14th Street was erected between 1885 and 1891, replacing an old brick hous.

March 31, 1930

P.L. Sperr

711307f-a.text:
14th Street, east from and including 333 West 14th Street, north side, east of Ninth Avenue, south side in shadow.  The double houses 325-7 and 309-11 West 14th Street are pictured individually in separate views made this same time. On the N.W. corner of Eighth Avenue may be seen the New York Savings Bank, the newer building erected not much before 1910.  the very new skyscraper at the N.E.  corner is the 20-story Lawyers County Trust company.  the fag is flying from the old Ninth Regiment Armory (now 244th Coast Artillery) west of Sixth Avenue.  In the background may be seen the tower of the new Consolidated Gas Building (1928)at the N.E. corner of Irving Place.

July 16, 1932

P. L. Sperr.

711301f-b.text:
(1)
14th Street, at and adjoining the N.W. corner of Hudson Street, where Hudson Street joins Ninth Avenue, showing the old houses at 686 Hudson Street and 355 West 14th Street, the stairway from the elevated station, and the skeleton of the new Port Authority Commerce Building, which is under construction in the block north of 15th Street and east of Ninth Avenue.
July 30, 1932.
P.L. Sperr

(2)
The same, missing the entire corner and showing all of 351-55 West 14th Street.
The time is nine months later, and the Port Authority Building is now completed.
March 12, 1933.
P.L. Sperr

711308f-a.text:
14th Street, west from Ninth Avenue, showing the West Side Elevated Highway (1930) and Pier 56, North River (the Cunerd Line) in the background.  The low three-story building opposite the northern end of Washington Street is the Gillen Building (between 1910 and 1916). Most of the taller buildings date from 1903 or later.  The eight-story building near Tenth Avenue, on the north side, was originally build for the American Can Company but has since been taken over by National Biscuit.

Piers 53 to 61, from Little West 12th Street to 21st Street, were built between 1902 and 1910 on the side of the old made-land waterfront.  Before that time, 14th Street extended west to the southern end of old Eleventh Avenue, which was as far west of Tenth Avenue as Tenth is west of Ninth.

April 10, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

Neg # 1569
